definition: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically one that is unwelcome.
example: The sudden drop in temperature was an aberration for this time of year.

definition: Angry and bitter in feeling, language, or tone.
example: The divorce proceedings were acrimonious, with both parties refusing to speak to each other.

definition: Liveliness and eagerness; cheerful readiness.
example: She accepted the task with great alacrity, eager to prove herself.

definition: To make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better or more tolerable.
example: Efforts were made to ameliorate the living conditions in the slums.

definition: Something belonging to a time other than that in which it exists; an error in chronological order.
example: The sword in the movie, set in the future, was a strange anachronism.

definition: Showing great care and perseverance; hardworking.
example: The research team was assiduous in collecting every piece of data.

definition: Severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance; simple and unadorned.
example: The headmaster maintained an austere and formal demeanor.

definition: Well meaning and kindly; serving a charitable purpose.
example: The benevolent organization donated books to the local school.

definition: To begin to grow or increase rapidly; flourish.
example: The small company quickly burgeoned into a massive enterprise.

definition: A harsh, jarring mixture of sounds.
example: A cacophony of car horns and sirens filled the busy street.

definition: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
example: Her capricious nature made her a difficult boss to work for.

definition: Wary and unwilling to take risks.
example: In a new environment, one must be very circumspect about whom they trust.

definition: Clear, logical, and convincing.
example: The student presented a cogent argument that swayed the entire class.

definition: An extensive fire that destroys a great deal of land or property.
example: The city’s greatest tragedy was the historic conflagration of 1871.

definition: Causing harm or damage.
example: The drought had a deleterious effect on the entire agricultural sector.

definition: To express contempt for; ridicule.
example: The critics derided the play as poorly written and poorly acted.

definition: Fundamentally different or distinct in kind; entirely unalike.
example: The team was composed of individuals with widely disparate skill sets.

definition: Cheerful and full of energy.
example: The winner gave an ebullient speech, thanking all of his supporters.

definition: Outstandingly bad; shocking.
example: It was an egregious error that cost the company millions in fines.

definition: To cause (someone) to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken.
example: The humid weather tends to enervate even the most energetic runners.

definition: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
example: He faced the crisis with impressive equanimity, never losing his cool.

definition: Demanding immediate attention; requiring much effort or attention.
example: The patient's condition was exigent, requiring an emergency operation.

definition: Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail; hard to please.
example: The chef was fastidious about the presentation of every dish.

definition: Silly and pointless; vacuously or complacently foolish.
example: He made a fatuous comment that showed he hadn't been listening.

definition: Producing or capable of producing an abundance of offspring or new growth; fertile.
example: The author’s fecund imagination produced three novels in a single year.

definition: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
example: The garrulous travel guide never stopped speaking during the entire bus tour.

definition: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.
example: The small island nation resisted the cultural hegemony of the neighboring superpower.

definition: Acting or done quickly and without thought or care; impulsive.
example: It was an impetuous decision to quit his job without a backup plan.

definition: Just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.
example: The project is still in an inchoate stage, lacking a clear strategy.

definition: To instill (an attitude, idea, or habit) by persistent instruction.
example: The parents tried to inculcate a love of reading in their children.

definition: Persisting tirelessly; incapable of being fatigued.
example: She was an indefatigable volunteer, working from dawn till dusk.

definition: Lacking the ability or strength to move; chemically inactive.
example: He lay inert on the couch, exhausted after the long run.

definition: Impossible to understand or interpret.
example: His expression remained inscrutable throughout the questioning.

definition: Lacking vigor or interest; dull.
example: The insipid plot of the movie failed to hold the audience's attention.

definition: Fearless; adventurous (often used for rhetorical or humorous effect).
example: The intrepid explorer ventured deep into the uncharted jungle.

definition: Displaying or having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed.
example: A languid afternoon spent relaxing in a hammock.

definition: Evil in nature or effect; malevolent. (Also a verb: to speak about someone in a spitefully critical manner.)
example: He was accused of trying to malign his former business partner.

definition: Sweet or musical; pleasant to hear.
example: The singer had a smooth, mellifluous voice that captivated the crowd.

definition: Not telling the truth; lying.
example: The politician's mendacious statements undermined public trust.

definition: A person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief; a novice.
example: As a neophyte in coding, she spent hours watching tutorial videos.

definition: To make obscure, unclear, or unintelligible.
example: The lawyer attempted to obfuscate the facts with confusing jargon.

definition: Involving an amount of effort and difficulty that is oppressively burdensome.
example: The teacher assigned the students an onerous amount of homework.

definition: A typical example or pattern of something; a model.
example: The invention of the internet created a new paradigm for commerce.

definition: An outcast; a person who is rejected or avoided by society.
example: After the scandal, the celebrity became a pariah in Hollywood.

definition: Translucently clear; easily understood.
example: The glass-bottom boat offered a view of the pellucid turquoise water.

definition: Deceitful and untrustworthy.
example: The general was court-martialed for his perfidious actions.

definition: Childishly sulky or bad-tempered.
example: The customer was petulant when the waiter brought the wrong order.

definition: A person who is hostile or indifferent to culture and the arts.
example: The museum director called the city council a group of philistines for cutting the arts budget.

definition: Slow and clumsy because of great weight; dull, laborious, or excessively solemn.
example: The speaker delivered a long and ponderous lecture on economic theory.

definition: Giving or indicating a good chance of success; favorable.
example: The timing for the launch was propitious, with good weather predicted.

definition: Eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight.
example: The drunk customer was in a pugnacious mood and looking for trouble.

definition: Beauty.
example: The actress was known for her exceptional pulchritude and charm.

definition: Exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.
example: The young man's quixotic dream of saving the entire rainforest was admirable but impossible.

definition: Bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing.
example: The decades-long family feud was filled with deep-seated rancor.

definition: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline.
example: The recalcitrant student refused to follow the teacher's instructions.

definition: Unable to keep still or silent and becoming increasingly difficult to control, especially due to impatience, dissatisfaction, or boredom.
example: The audience grew restive during the excessively long intermission.

definition: Making a show of being morally superior to other people.
example: His sanctimonious pronouncements on charity alienated many of his colleagues.

definition: A servile flatterer; a person who acts obsequiously to gain advantage.
example: The manager ignored the sycophant's excessive compliments.

definition: Expressing or favoring a particular cause or view; biased.
example: The newspaper was criticized for its tendentious coverage of the election.

definition: A false, absurd, or distorted representation of something.
example: The judge called the trial a travesty of justice.
